citeinfo.title: EnviroAtlas - Commute Time to Work by Census Block Group for the Conterminous United States

pubinfo.publish: US EPA Office of Research and Development (ORD) - National Exposure Research Laboratory (NERL)

idinfo.useconst: None. Please check sources, scale, accuracy, currentness and other available information. Please confirm that you are using the most recent copy of both data and metadata. Acknowledgement of the EPA would be appreciated.

descript.abstract: This EnviroAtlas dataset portrays the commute time of workers to their workplace for each Census Block Group (CBG) during 2008-2012. Data were compiled from the Census ACS (American Community Survey) 5-year Summary Data. The commute time is the amount of travel time in minutes for workers to get from home to work. This value includes private vehicle use, carpooling, public transit, bicycling, or walking. This dataset was produced by the US EPA to support research and online mapping activities related to EnviroAtlas. EnviroAtlas (https://www.epa.gov/enviroatlas) allows the user to interact with a web-based, easy-to-use, mapping application to view and analyze multiple ecosystem services for the contiguous United States. The dataset is available as downloadable data (https://edg.epa.gov/data/Public/ORD/EnviroAtlas) or as an EnviroAtlas map service. Additional descriptive information about each attribute in this dataset can be found in its associated EnviroAtlas Fact Sheet (https://www.epa.gov/enviroatlas/enviroatlas-fact-sheets).
descript.purpose: This dataset presents the patterns of commute time of working populations. Commute time is a measure of the efficiency of a transportation system and is often influenced by community development patterns, labor market shifts, and technological changes that expand workers' options for where and how to work (ACS, 2011). A high commute time can signify a sprawled region and/or a lack of efficient transit, while a low commute time implies a dense region and/or an efficient transit system. Long commute time contributes to increased air pollution as cars, buses, or trains emit pollutants while moving and sitting idle in traffic, while a short commute time contributes to lower emissions. Commute time has also been shown to affect human health and social relationships. Growing evidence supports the association between vehicle travel time and stress (Frumkin, 2002), obesity (Frank et al., 2004; Lopez-Zetina et al., 2006; Inagami et al., 2006), and diabetes (Pasala et al., 2010). Additionally, long automobile commuting duration could affect quality of life by reducing the amount of time spent with family and friends (Christian, 2012). The overall goal of EnviroAtlas is to employ and develop the best available science to map indicators of ecosystem services production, demand, and drivers for the nation.

cntperp.cntorg: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Office of Research and Development-Sustainable and Healthy Communities Research Program, EnviroAtlas

dataqual.logic: Tests for integrity have not been performed.
dataqual.complete: Features represented have not been tested for completeness

horizpa.horizpar: Data were collected using methods that have unknown accuracy (EPA National Geospatial Data Policy [NGDP] Accuracy Tier 10). For more information, please see EPA's NGDP at https://www.epa.gov/geospatial/geospatial-policies-and-standards

procstep.procdesc: Used Summary File Retrieval Tool to download ACS 5-year 2008-2012 data (http://www2.census.gov/acs2012_5yr/summaryfile/UserTools/SummaryFileDataRetrievalTool.zip).
Downloaded the ACS 5-year 2008-2012 summary file Table B08303 (http://www.census.gov/acs/www/data_documentation/summary_file/).
Joined the summary file to TIGER/Line Shapefiles using the GEOID.

The ACS commute times were reclassified into four categories: commute time less than 30 minutes (column 2 to 7), from 30 to 60 minutes (column 8 to 11), from 60 to 90 minutes (column 12), and more than 90 minutes (column 13).
The percentage of workers in each commute time category was calculated by dividing the number of workers by column 1 (total workers 16 years and over who did not work at home).
Data quality checking and making corrections.

enttyp.enttypd: Commute times to work by block group.

attr.attrdef: Census block group identifier; a concatenation of 2010 Census state Federal Information Processing Standards (FIPS) code, county FIPS code, census tract code, and block group number

codesetd.codesetn: INCITS.38-200x (R2004), Codes for the Identification of the States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and the Insular Areas of the United States (Formerly FIPS 5-2), INCITS.31-200x (R2007), Codes for the Identification of the Counties and Equivalent Areas of the United States, Puerto Rico, and the Insular Areas of the United States (Formerly FIPS 6-4) and the tract code that appears in TRACTCE10 and the census block group number that appears in BLKGRPCE10

attr.attrdef: Percentage of workers with less than 30 minutes travel time to work.

Percentage of workers with less than 30 minutes travel time to work.

Percentage of workers with travel time to work ranging from 60 to 90 minutes.

overview.eaover:
For more information about EnviroAtlas data, go to https://www.epa.gov/enviroatlas/enviroatlas-fact-sheets. This dataset portrays the commute time of workers to their workplace for each Census Block Group (CBG) during 2008-2012. Data were compiled from the Census ACS (American Community Survey) 5-year Summary Data. The commute time is the amount of travel time in minutes for workers to get from home to work. This value includes private vehicle use, carpooling, public transit, bicycling, or walking.
ACS obtained the data through survey questions related to travel; these questions focus solely on commuting and do not ask about leisure travel or other non-work trips. This dataset includes commuting characteristics for workers 16 years and over who were employed during the week prior to the ACS reference week and did not work at home. Persons on vacation or not at work the prior week are not included. Respondents answer questions about where they work, what time they leave home for work, the means of transportation used to get there, the number of workers riding in a car, truck, or van, and how long it takes to travel to work.
A comprehensive list of metric creation steps is included in the Processing Steps. The processing scripts were completed using Python scripts.
References: American Community Survey (ACS). 2011. Technical Report: Out-of-State and Long commutes: 2011. Frank L. D., Andresen M. A., Schmid T. L. Obesity relationships with community design, physical activity, and time spent in cars. Am J Prev Med. 2004; 27(2):87–96. Frumkin, H. (2002). Urban sprawl and public health. Public health reports, 117(3), 201. Lopez-Zetina, J., Lee, H., and Friis, R. (2006). The link between obesity and the built environment. Evidence from an ecological analysis of obesity and vehicle miles of travel in California. Health & Place, 12(4), 656-664. Inagami S., Cohen D. A., Finch B. K., Asch S. M. You are where you shop: grocery store locations, weight, and neighborhoods. Am J Prev Med. 2006;31(1):10–17. Christian, T. J. (2012). Automobile commuting duration and the quantity of time spent with spouse, children, and friends. Preventive medicine, 55(3), 215-218. Pasala, S. K., Rao, A. A., and Sridhar, G. R. (2010). Built environment and diabetes. International journal of diabetes in developing countries, 30(2), 63.
